note_text:
Data:

Patient: 48-year-old female presents with a new lump in the right breast, discovered during self-exam six weeks ago. Reports gradual enlargement and occasional tenderness, denies nipple discharge or systemic symptoms. Past medical history includes hypertension, controlled with lisinopril; no prior malignancies. Family history significant for maternal breast cancer at age 55.

On exam, a 2.6 cm firm irregular mass is palpated at the 10 o’clock position of the right breast with mild overlying skin puckering. Right axilla shows a single mobile enlarged lymph node. Contralateral breast and systemic exam unremarkable.

Diagnostic workup: Mammogram and ultrasound demonstrate a suspicious irregular lesion, BI-RADS 5. Core biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, ER 90% positive, PR 20% positive, HER2 negative, Ki-67 22%. MRI shows no multifocal disease; CT chest/abdomen/pelvis reveals no distant metastasis.

Assessment: Newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma, right breast, clinical stage IIB (cT2N1M0), hormone receptor–positive, HER2-negative.

Plan: Refer to surgical oncology for discussion of lumpectomy versus mastectomy with axillary staging. Send tissue for Oncotype DX testing to guide adjuvant chemotherapy decision. Initiate endocrine therapy following surgery. Anticipate radiation post-lumpectomy. Provide referral for genetic counseling and psychosocial support services. Follow-up after tumor board discussion.

Patient: 50-year-old female
Date of Service: 09/05/2025
Provider: Dr. Name, MD – Breast Oncology

Chief Complaint: “I felt a lump in my right breast a few months ago.”

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 50-year-old postmenopausal woman who presents with a new palpable mass in the right breast, first noticed approximately four months ago during self-exam. The mass has gradually increased in size and is associated with occasional dull pain. She reports subtle nipple inversion but denies discharge, bleeding, or overlying erythema. No systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss. She underwent a screening mammogram 14 months ago, which was normal.

Past Medical History:
	•	Hypertension, on lisinopril.
	•	Hyperlipidemia, on atorvastatin.
	•	No prior malignancies.

Family History:
	•	Sister diagnosed with breast cancer at age 47.
	•	Maternal aunt with ovarian cancer.

Social History:
	•	Married, works as an attorney.
	•	Never smoked, occasional social alcohol use.
	•	Exercises regularly.

Physical Exam:
	•	Vitals stable.
	•	Right breast: palpable firm, irregular 3.8 cm mass at 9 o’clock position with mild skin retraction. Nipple partially inverted.
	•	Axilla: two palpable, mobile right axillary nodes.
	•	Left breast: no abnormalities.
	•	No supraclavicular adenopathy.

Diagnostics:
	•	Mammogram/Ultrasound: Irregular spiculated mass, BI-RADS 5, with suspicious axillary nodes.
	•	Core Needle Biopsy: Invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II. ER 90% positive, PR 50% positive, HER2 negative, Ki-67 28%.
	•	MRI: Confirms primary lesion, no additional lesions.
	•	CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis: No evidence of metastasis.

Assessment:
50-year-old female with newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, hormone receptor–positive, HER2–, grade II, with axillary involvement. Staging consistent with clinical stage IIB (cT2N1M0).

Plan:
	1.	Surgery: Candidate for breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) with axillary dissection versus mastectomy; decision pending patient preference and tumor board discussion.
	2.	Systemic therapy: Send Oncotype DX to evaluate chemotherapy benefit. Plan for adjuvant endocrine therapy (aromatase inhibitor).
	3.	Radiation therapy: Anticipated post-lumpectomy.
	4.	Genetics: Referral for BRCA and other germline mutation testing due to family history.
	5.	Supportive care: Referral to oncology social worker and support group. Nutritional counseling recommended.
	6.	Follow-up: Review Oncotype results and finalize surgical plan after tumor board.

Dr. Name, MD

Patient presents with a 3-day history of productive cough, reporting greenish sputum, mild dyspnea, and intermittent fever peaking at 101°F. Denies chest pain, hemoptysis, or recent travel. Past medical history significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril.

- General: Alert and oriented; no acute distress.

Patient: 55-year-old female
Date: 09/05/2025
Provider: Dr. Name, MD – Breast Oncology

Chief Complaint: “I found a lump in my left breast about three months ago.”

History of Present Illness:
The patient noticed a firm lump in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast during routine self-examination. Over three months, she has perceived gradual enlargement, intermittent aching pain, and subtle dimpling of the skin. She denies nipple discharge, redness, or warmth. No fevers, chills, or unexplained weight loss. Screening mammogram last year was normal.

Past Medical History: Hypertension, hypothyroidism. No history of cancer.
Family History: Mother with ovarian cancer, sister with breast cancer at age 49.
Social History: Nonsmoker, occasional alcohol, retired accountant.

Exam: Left breast palpable 3.5 cm irregular, firm, non-mobile mass at 2 o’clock position. Mild skin retraction noted. Left axilla reveals two firm nodes. No supraclavicular nodes. Right breast normal.

Diagnostics:
	•	Mammogram/Ultrasound: Irregular mass, BI-RADS 5.
	•	Core Biopsy: Invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, ER 95% positive, PR 30% positive, HER2 negative (IHC 0). Ki-67: 25%.
	•	Breast MRI: Confirms primary lesion, no multifocal disease.
	•	CT chest/abdomen/pelvis: No distant metastases.

Assessment: Newly diagnosed left breast invasive ductal carcinoma, clinical stage IIB (cT2N1M0), hormone receptor–positive, HER2-negative.

Plan:
	1.	Surgical oncology consultation for breast-conserving surgery vs. mastectomy with axillary dissection.
	2.	Oncotype DX testing to guide chemotherapy decision.
	3.	Adjuvant endocrine therapy post-surgery (likely aromatase inhibitor).
	4.	Radiation therapy anticipated following lumpectomy.
	5.	Genetic counseling for BRCA mutation testing.
	6.	Psychosocial support referral, patient education on treatment options.
	7.	Follow-up after multidisciplinary tumor board review.

Signature:
Dr. Name, MD

52-year-old female presents with a palpable mass in the left breast, first noted two months ago. Mammogram and ultrasound revealed a 3.1 cm spiculated lesion in the upper outer quadrant with suspicious axillary lymphadenopathy. Core biopsy confirmed invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II, ER+/PR+, HER2–, Ki-67 18%. Staging CT negative for metastasis. Exam notable for firm irregular mass with mild skin dimpling; axillary nodes palpable. Assessment: stage II breast cancer (cT2N1M0). Plan: surgical oncology referral for lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy, Oncotype DX testing, adjuvant endocrine therapy, and post-operative radiation.

Clinical Note

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
MRN: [REDACTED]
Date of Service: 09/05/2025
Provider: Dr. Name, MD (Oncology)
Location: Best Cancer Center – Breast Oncology Clinic

⸻

Chief Complaint

“Left breast lump noticed two months ago, progressively increasing in size.”

⸻

History of Present Illness

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents with concerns regarding a palpable lump in her left breast, first noted during self-examination approximately two months ago. The lump has gradually increased in size and is now associated with intermittent dull pain and mild tenderness. The patient denies nipple discharge, skin changes, erythema, or axillary swelling at onset, but over the last two weeks she has noticed subtle dimpling of the overlying skin.

The patient underwent screening mammography 10 months ago, which was reportedly normal. She has not had genetic testing for breast cancer risk. She has not noticed systemic symptoms such as weight loss, fevers, or night sweats.

⸻

Past Medical History
	•	Hypertension, well controlled on lisinopril.
	•	Hyperlipidemia.
	•	No known diabetes.
	•	No previous malignancies.

⸻

Past Surgical History
	•	Cesarean section x2.
	•	No prior breast surgery or biopsies.

⸻

Family History
	•	Mother diagnosed with breast cancer at age 61.
	•	Maternal aunt with ovarian cancer.
	•	Father with coronary artery disease.

⸻

Social History
	•	Lives with husband.
	•	Two adult children.
	•	Non-smoker, drinks wine occasionally.
	•	Works as a high school teacher.
	•	No illicit drug use.

⸻

Medications
	•	Lisinopril 20 mg PO daily.
	•	Atorvastatin 20 mg PO daily.
	•	Vitamin D supplement.

⸻

Allergies
	•	NKDA.

⸻

Review of Systems
	•	General: No fevers, chills, weight loss.
	•	Breast: Palpable left breast lump, mild tenderness, skin dimpling.
	•	Cardiac/Respiratory: No chest pain, no shortness of breath.
	•	GI: No abdominal pain, no nausea/vomiting.
	•	Neuro: No focal weakness, no headaches.

⸻

Physical Examination

Vital Signs: BP 128/76, HR 78, Temp 36.8°C, RR 16, SpO₂ 99% RA.

General: Alert, oriented, no acute distress.
Breast Exam: Left breast palpable firm irregular mass, approximately 3.2 cm in diameter, located at 2 o’clock position, 4 cm from the nipple. Mild skin dimpling noted. No nipple retraction or discharge. Right breast normal.
Lymph Nodes: Palpable left axillary lymphadenopathy, firm and mobile. No supraclavicular or cervical adenopathy.
Cardiac/Respiratory/Abdomen/Neuro: Within normal limits.

⸻

Diagnostic Studies
	1.	Mammography (08/15/2025):
	•	Spiculated mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast, 3.0 cm, BI-RADS 5.
	•	Suspicious axillary lymph node.
	2.	Breast Ultrasound (08/20/2025):
	•	Confirms solid irregular hypoechoic lesion, 3.1 x 2.8 cm.
	•	Suspicious left axillary node.
	3.	Core Needle Biopsy (08/25/2025):
	•	Invasive ductal carcinoma, grade II.
	•	Estrogen receptor (ER) positive, 85%.
	•	Progesterone receptor (PR) positive, 40%.
	•	HER2 negative (IHC 0).
	•	Ki-67 proliferation index: 18%.
	4.	Staging MRI (09/01/2025):
	•	Confirms index lesion in left breast, no multifocal disease.
	•	Left axillary lymphadenopathy.
	•	No evidence of chest wall invasion.
	5.	CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis (09/02/2025):
	•	No distant metastases identified.

⸻

Assessment

52-year-old female with newly diagnosed left breast invasive ductal carcinoma, stage II (cT2N1M0). Tumor is ER+/PR+, HER2–, intermediate grade. Disease localized to left breast and ipsilateral axillary lymph nodes without evidence of distant spread.

⸻

Plan
	1.	Oncology Referral: Patient counseled regarding treatment options, including surgery, systemic therapy, and radiation.
	2.	Surgical Oncology: Candidate for breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) with sentinel node biopsy vs. axillary dissection. Will meet with surgical oncology next week.
	3.	Medical Oncology: Based on ER+/PR+ and HER2– status, adjuvant systemic therapy to include endocrine therapy. Chemotherapy decision pending Oncotype DX testing.
	4.	Radiation Oncology: Post-lumpectomy radiation anticipated.
	5.	Genetic Counseling: Referral for BRCA and other hereditary cancer panel given family history.
	6.	Supportive Care: Discussed psychosocial support, nutrition, and exercise. Patient provided with information on breast cancer support groups.
	7.	Follow-Up: Return to clinic after surgical consultation for multidisciplinary tumor board review.

⸻

Provider Signature:
Dr. Name, MD
Best Cancer Center – Breast Oncology
